Later in the story, however, Waters writes, "Now that Saburo was an adult, their conversations were no longer awkward," and, "His father, he realized, had a passionate side." In this, Waters tries to convey to the reader that Saburo has experienced a change in feelings toward his father; he is now able to enjoy his father's company without the awkwardness.

The relationship of Saburo and his father was awkward and strained at first. Saburo described that his father had a stoic nature because he came from the war and helped rebuild Japan from ashes. After Saburo joined the track and field team, his father offered to take him to Kaigane Station to clock his runs. Although Saburo's father never attended his competitions, he always "inquired after the results at dinner." Saburo simply stated that his father "was an academic" to justify why his father never attended the competitions. The rides to Kaigane Station was often silent: "they sat gingerly side by side in the streetcar.. It was awkward and silent." Because of this, Saburo often "wished his father were like his friends' fathers: sun-browned, guffawing men who ruffled children's hair with affectionate ease." Even though their relationship was often awkward and tense, Saburo's father always encouraged Saburo to not think about how other runners do during the race; he encouraged Saburo to focus on beating his time so that he can improve. At the end, Saburo realized that his father was a very passionate person, whose "voice rose with fervor, [coming] to a full stop in order to make his point," and their relationship was more at ease, allowing them to have conversations that were no longer awkward.

Though Saburo and his father's relationship might not seem affectionate to one's naked eye, their relationship is stronger than it seems. To Saburo and his father, their bond of accomplishing something together was an expression of what people might call the "stereotypical-father-son" relationship. For example, when Saburo quit the track team to focus on his college entrance examinations, he "felt guilty over ending their sessions", in other words, he loved that time he had spent with his father. As Saburo grew up, he realized his father had a "passionate side". According to Saburo's youthful experience, his father was a stoic man, but Saburo learned that he was indeed his father's son.
